text:
I need help with the right word.

Most thought leadership articles are one of the following types:
-- What: an introduction to a topic
-- When: A trend piece on a topic, maybe why it's relevant now
-- Why: an essay that convinces you why something is important or warrants attention
-- How: how to do a thing

I think of these types as being the "shape" of the article. Because like a yoga pose, the type of article informs the actual visual shape. Like a "How" article will most commonly be steps, so you'll have a short intro with at least three H1s all of similar size. Whereas a "Why" article will often have a much longer introduction as you set context.

Does this resonate with anyone else? Is there a better word for these types than shape?

user_profile.real_name: Janessa Lantz, VP of Marketing at dbt Labs
user_profile.name: janessalantz

text: I 100% get what you're saying and usually refer to that as the 'structure' or 'scaffolding' of the article

elements.text: I 100% get what you're saying and usually refer to that as the 'structure' or 'scaffolding' of the article

text: Yeah, someone in another group suggested structure which I think works here. I think of structure as being more closely linked to the H1s and H2s. So  in my mind, the structure of a post should align with the chosen "shape" but they are still different things.  Another person suggested genre which I like.

text: 100%! Content has a shape! In journalism there is even the “pyramid” style of writing… I really like “pose” as you used it because it’s considered and aesthetic. Other words that came to mind: form, flow, format, recipe

elements.text: 100%! Content has a shape! In journalism there is even the “pyramid” style of writing… I really like “pose” as you used it because it’s considered and aesthetic. Other words that came to mind: form, flow, format, recipe

text: Yeah! It is a bit like the pyramid! I bet I could further outline types of say "How" articles and create recipes. Ex: the "How to do X" article is a great format for really tactical posts whereas the "How I did X" article is better for senior people writing about strategic changes (or growth hackers looking to brag about some hyped conversion number :joy:)

text:
You could try doing a series of blogs that are clickable between each one - kind of the same as a series of ebooks/chapters as mentioned before. You could then have one main blog which you promote that has hyperlinks to all the separate areas. You could also corporate video content/GIFs/visuals throughout the blogs to make them interactive. 

I've also seen some interactive landing pages hold ungated content! That way, as a user scrolls, information is revealed with animations (not sure what software can be used for this though)

elements.text:

I've also seen some interactive landing pages hold ungated content! That way, as a user scrolls, information is revealed with animations (not sure what software can be used for this though)

text: Have you thought about recording some tutorial videos or sharing some content around how your services could be used in new and exciting ways? We're a SaaS company and we record "product tour" videos that show new users how to use our software inventive ways. We also often use examples from our clients to illustrate our points :blush:

text:
Yep! But does that shape always align with the Why, How, What? I think so.

Any how-to article is going to have 3-5 sections that are all roughly the same size. But Why articles often have much longer introductions with more varied sections. What articles have a little more variation in the sections, but shorter introductions. A long intro on a "what" article means you're spending too much time convincing the reader that the What matters which means it should be a Why article.

Do you buy that?

user_profile.real_name: Janessa Lantz, VP of Marketing at dbt Labs
user_profile.name: janessalantz

text: Tangential but this "shape" talk reminds me of Charlie Stross's (sci-fi author) who talked about book economics and how it didn't matter the true length of your story, for it to be commercially viable it had to fit within 250-500 pages (generally) due to some specific ways in which physical books were printed+bound.

text:
I need some help with a piece that I'm writing.

What do you think are the core differences between a growth/digital marketer vs. a product marketer?

elements.text:
I need some help with a piece that I'm writing.

What do you think are the core differences between a growth/digital marketer vs. a product marketer?

text: Honestly, it's just total nuance. The growth marketer at one company is the product marketer at another. This is especially true at early stage companies (or new products at later stage companies).

elements.text: Honestly, it's just total nuance. The growth marketer at one company is the product marketer at another. This is especially true at early stage companies (or new products at later stage companies).

text: For me, I think that the product marketer is more closely tied with the product development and working between marketing, the product team, and sales. Then, getting that message out into the world.

elements.text: For me, I think that the product marketer is more closely tied with the product development and working between marketing, the product team, and sales. Then, getting that message out into the world.

text: The growth marketer has KPIs more closely related to new users and is more likely to own the paid marketing channels than a product marketer may (at a more developed company).

elements.text: The growth marketer has KPIs more closely related to new users and is more likely to own the paid marketing channels than a product marketer may (at a more developed company).

text: +1 to the nuance. At Eventbrite, they were separate. Growth marketers were focused on optimizing behavioral triggers in the acquisition funnel. Product marketers were focused on messaging for product launches.

elements.text: +1 to the nuance. At Eventbrite, they were separate. Growth marketers were focused on optimizing behavioral triggers in the acquisition funnel. Product marketers were focused on messaging for product launches.
